name: csvtk

options.description: chunk size of CSV reader (default 50)
lines starting with commment-character will be ignored. if your header row starts with '#', please assign "-C" another rare symbol, e.g. '$' (default "#")
delimiting character of the input CSV file (default ",")
help for csvtk
ignore empty rows
ignore illegal rows
file of input files list (one file per line), if given, they are appended to files from cli arguments
if given, a quote may appear in an unquoted field and a non-doubled quote may appear in a quoted field
specifies that the input CSV file does not have header row
number of CPUs to use (default value depends on your computer) (default 12)
delimiting character of the output CSV file, e.g., -D $'\t' for tab (default ",")
out file ("-" for stdout, suffix .gz for gzipped out) (default "-")
specifies that the output is delimited with tabs. Overrides "-D"

subcommands.name: grep

options.description: delete a pattern right after being matched, this keeps the firstly matched data and speedups when using regular expressions

print output immediately, do not use write buffer
invert match

no highlight

pattern files (one pattern per line)

subcommands.name: join
subcommands.description: join files by selected fields (inner, left and outer join)

options.description: Semicolon separated key fields of all files, if given one, we think all the files have the same key columns. Fields of different files should be separated by ";", e.g -f "1;2" or -f "A,B;C,D" or -f id (default "1")
using fuzzy fields, e.g., -F -f "*name" or -F -f "id123*"
help for join
ignore case
keep unmatched data of the first file (left join)
left join, equals to -k/--keep-unmatched, exclusive with --outer-join
content for filling NA data
outer join, exclusive with --left-join

tldr:
> Manipulate CSV and TSV files

- Prettify table:

`csvtk pretty {{test.csv}}`

- Select columns with headers named first_name and last_name:

`cat {{test.csv}} | csvtk cut -f {{first_name,last_name}} | csvtk pretty`

- Rename headers from first_name to FirstName, and from last_name to LastName:

`cat {{test.csv}} | csvtk rename -f {{first_name,last_name}} -n {{FirstName,LastName}}`

- Sort by age and last_name columns:

`csvtk sort -k {{age,last_name}}`

- Join files by username column in the first file, and name in the second:

`csvtk join -f {{"username;name"}} {{phone.csv}} {{adress.csv}} -k`

- Select rows with age columns greater than 30:

`csvtk filter -f {{"age>30"}}`
